item.title: Germany's Plans Are Big, But Not Big Enough, KKR's Vincent Policard Says
item.description: The German cabinet has approved plans to spend €500B on infrastructure over the next 12 years, but KKR's Vincent Policard says it's not enough. KKR has invested billions in Germany over the past few years, and Policard says private capital will be key. He spoke to Bloomberg's Tom Mackenzie on "Daybreak Europe" on June 25. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: JSW Agrees to Buy Akzo Nobel India Unit in $1.6 Billion Deal
item.description: JSW Group agreed to buy up to 75% of Akzo Nobel NV’s Indian business as the Indian conglomerate seeks to expand its presence in areas such as paints.
item.dc:creator: Baiju Kalesh, Sanjai P R

media:content.media:description: Paint spread test sheets at an Akzo Nobel India paint factory in Gwalior, Madhya Pradesh, India.

item.title: Asian Stocks Rise on Trade-Deal Hope, Fed Cut Bets: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian stocks advanced and a gauge of global equities was on track for another record high on trade-deal optimism and increased expectations for Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts this year.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Ossinger

item.title: ‘Revenge Tax’ Shift Revives US Appeal for Australia Mega Funds
item.description: Australia’s A$4.1 trillion ($2.7 trillion) pension industry signaled relief over US plans to scrap the so-called “revenge tax,” which would have increased levies on income from assets of foreign investors.
item.dc:creator: Amy Bainbridge, Richard Henderson

media:content.media:description: Buildings in Sydney. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Steadies at End of Turbulent Week as Focus Shifts to Tariffs
item.description: Oil headed for the biggest weekly decline in two years after a ceasefire between Israel and Iran, with focus shifting from the conflict in the Middle East to US trade negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: Oil storage tanks in Richmond, California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Five Years From Wirecard, Europe’s Shorts Are Still Unloved
item.description: If you want to short a dodgy company in Europe, good luck keeping it secret.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hughes

media:content.media:description: A folder marked 'Ba Fin IV' and other legal documents and books on a trolley at the inquiry into the collapse of Wirecard AG at the German Bundestag’s Paul-Loebe-Haus in Berlin, Germany, on Friday, April 23, 2021. Wirecard revealed in June last year that 1.9 billion euros ($2.3 billion) it had reported as assets probably never existed, rattling Germany’s finance industry and damaging the country’s reputation.

item.title: Thai Rate Pause Is Lifeline Saved for Turbulence Ahead, BOT Says
item.description: The Bank of Thailand’s decision to leave borrowing costs unchanged this week gives it a “monetary lifeline” to deal with challenges ranging from US tariffs and geopolitical tensions to domestic politics, according to Deputy Governor Piti Disyatat.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Thomas Kutty Abraham

item.title: Taiwanese Investors Flee US Bond ETFs as Currency Risks Mount
item.description: Taiwanese investors are unloading their holdings in US-focused exchange-traded bond funds at the quickest pace since the onset of the Covid pandemic, highlighting a “Sell America” momentum that may further boost the island’s currency.
item.dc:creator: Betty Hou

item.title: Mexico Steps In to Run Banks Tarred by US Drug Accusations
item.description: Mexico’s bank regulator stepped in to temporarily run three financial firms on Thursday, an extraordinary measure aimed at protecting customers following money-laundering accusations by US authorities the day before.
item.dc:creator: Michael O'Boyle

media:content.media:description: People pass by a CIBanco branch in Mexico City on June 25, 2025. On Wednesday, the US Treasury banned certain transactions with Mexican financial institutions CIBanco, Intercam Banco, and Vector Casa de Bolsa as part of its new sanctions related to fentanyl. (Photo by Alfredo ESTRELLA / AFP) (Photo by ALFREDO ESTRELLA/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Japan Braces for Further Pain From US Tariffs, Pledges Support
item.description: Japan will take additional action to ease the impact of US tariffs on the auto sector as needed and “without hesitation,” its economy minister says.
item.dc:creator: Komaki Ito

item.title: The Asia Trade 06/27/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Tokyo and Sydney with Shery Ahn and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: China’s Industrial Profits Sink on US Tariffs, Deflation Woes
item.description: China’s industrial firms saw their profits drop the most since October, illustrating weakness in an economy strained by higher US tariffs and lingering deflationary pressure.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, Fran Wang

media:content.media:description: Workers on the production line at a kitchen utensils factory near Zhuhai, China.

item.title: Taiwan Dollar Rises Past 29 Per Greenback for the First Time Since 2022
item.description: The Taiwan dollar climbed past a key psychological level for the first time in more than three years, pressuring the island’s export reliant economy and life insurers with large foreign-exchange exposures.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Burgess, Betty Hou

item.title: Allianz's Zeng on Fed Rate, De-Dollarization
item.description: Jenny Zeng, Allianz Global Investors Deputy Head of Fixed Income & APAC Fixed Income CIO, speaks on Bloomberg TV about the Fed rate and the trend of de-dollarization. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Moody’s Downgrades Colombia Citing Suspension of Fiscal Rule
item.description: Moody’s Ratings and S&P Global Ratings downgraded Colombia’s credit, citing the worsening debt burden and the decision to suspend the fiscal rule that curbed government borrowing.
item.dc:creator: Nicolle Yapur

media:content.media:description: Traffic in Bogota, Colombia, on Friday, Dec. 20, 2024. Colombia’s central bank unexpectedly slowed its monetary easing campaign as fiscal concerns are weakening the nation’s currency and adding to inflation risks.

item.title: India Earnings Set to Outperform China on Domestic Growth and Tariff Edge
item.description: Indian companies are inspiring more optimism than their Chinese rivals for next earnings season.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo, Harshita Swaminathan

item.title: Bain Capital on Virgin Australia Post-IPO Outlook
item.description: Barnaby Lyons, Global Head of Special Situations at Bain Capital, discusses his outlook for Virgin Australia's business, after the airline re-listed on the ASX in a $440 million IPO. He also speaks about the broader outlook for APAC private market activities. He speaks with Haidi Stroud Watts on "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade". (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nikkei Hits 40,000 Level as Trade Hopes Drive Japan Stock Rally
item.description: Japanese shares rose for a fourth day on trade optimism after the US and China signed a deal and the White House hinted Donald Trump may soften his July tariff deadline.
item.dc:creator: Alice French, Toshiro Hasegawa

media:content.media:description: An electronic ticker at the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) in Tokyo, Japan. Photographer: Kiyoshi Ota/Bloomberg

item.title: Lutnick Says US-China Trade Truce Signed
item.description: The US and China have finalized a trade understanding reached last month in Geneva, which includes China's commitment to deliver rare earths used in various industries. That's according to US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick. Bloomberg's Minmin Low reports on the latest. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: New World Gets 100% Lender Approval for $11 Billion Refinancing
item.description: Distressed Hong Kong builder New World Development Co. has secured written commitments from all banks for a HK$87.5 billion ($11.1 billion) loan refinancing, people familiar with the matter said, bringing it closer to finalizing the critical lifeline just days before a deadline.
item.dc:creator: Apple Ka Ying Li, Jackie Cai, Pearl Liu

media:content.media:description: A New World Development Co. project in Hong Kong. Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

item.title: South Korea Mulls More Debt Sales After Its Largest Euro Bond
item.description: The South Korean government may tap foreign debt markets again in the second half after pricing its largest-ever euro-denominated bond offering on Thursday, according to the nation’s finance ministry.
item.dc:creator: Haram Lim

media:content.media:description: The National Assembly building in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday, April 7, 2025. South Korea has set June 3 as the tentative date for the next presidential election, Yonhap News reported on Monday, citing an unidentified government official.

item.title: Japan Pension Shuns Bonds With 57% of Fund in Alternative Assets
item.description: Japan’s once conservative pension funds are putting more of their cash in alternative assets to push up returns. One corporate money manager has taken that to a whole new level.
item.dc:creator: Nao Sano

item.title: Sanctioned Russian LNG Plant Looks Set to Restart Exports
item.description: A liquefied natural gas tanker appears to have docked at a Russian Arctic export plant sanctioned by the US for the first time in eight months, in what is likely Moscow’s latest attempt to expand deliveries of the fuel.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Anna Shiryaevskaya

item.title: Funds Flexing 60/40 Playbook Become Investor Favorites in India
item.description: Indian funds that offer built-in diversification by combining stocks with assets such as bonds and gold lured in more money than pure equity ones last month for the first time in a year, pointing toward a potential long-term investment shift.
item.dc:creator: Divya Patil, Ashutosh Joshi
